title: Fans' 'hits and misses' from Afcon - SuperSport - Football
text:
Fans' 'hits and misses' from Afcon by Collins Okinyo 03 February 2017, 08:49 Tweet Afcon 2017 is drawing to and end with the last two teams, Egypt and Cameroon, left standing. Both will be facing each other on Sunday deploying the same style of reactionary football, so it certainly will be final be worth seeing. In the meantime our man in Gabon, Collins Okinyo with the help of our Afcon editorial staff, have been compiling a list of sound bites, utterances , highlights and flops from the tournament which we now present with a slight sprinkling of African humour. We hope you enjoy the read and not be offended by any item on our list of hits and misses. 
Mark Gleason : With his ability to pronounce our African names properly, be they Wolof or Berber, Bantu or Ashanti, as well as his astute knowledge of the game and mind-blowing facts, Gleason has again demonstrated why he is without a doubt Africa’s best play by play commentator. HIT 
Substitution error : Ghana V Uganda - Andre Ayew substituting Andre Ayew. MISS 
Best substitution: Burkina V Morocco – Aristide Bance who took just four minutes to strike gold. HIT 
Best goal celebration: player Junior Kabananga HIT 
Best goal celebration: team (TIE) DRC’s ‘Lets gyrate and flog’ and Ghana’s ‘Driving the bus together’ dances HIT 
Most vocal fans: (TIE) Burkina Faso and DRC HIT 
Best quote: Coach ‘Micho’s law of relativity quote before Ghana V Uganda – ‘What goes up must eventually, come down’. HIT 
Saddest Moment: An inconsolable Mane being led off the pitch by his coach Cisse (below) , who will be linked forever by history, for both missing the crucial penalty against Cameroon 15 years apart. JUST SAD 
Fans favourite snack: Nyembwe. A mouth-watering dish of chicken and spicy palm pulp. It’s so good that it is the national dish not just of Gabon, but of the two Congo’s as well. HIT 
Fans favourite drink : Régab beer. Though not allowed in the stadia, it can be purchased within spitting distance even in the morning, and sometimes even cheaper than water. HIT 
Mr. Forever Young: El Hadry HIT 
Most common mode of transportation: Taxi Brousse is the usual transport means for many fans while in Libreville they are called Matatus. Here the system puzzled many foreigners, because one has to shout your intended destination, the number of seats you need, and the price you are offering over all the din of traffic at the driver, who can either accept, or simply drive off without saying a word. MISS 
Worst miss: AAubameyang against Cameroon MISS 
Best goal : Bance's bomb against Morocco because of the consequence YOU TELL US! 
Best jersey: Mali (TIE) Mali’s Eagle across the chest and Senegal's roaring Lion kits HIT 
Worst jersey: (TIE) Zimbabwe – unbranded against Algeria and Ghana aimed at mimicking Germany but it was too busy, and they ended up playing like Bangladesh against Cameroon MISS 
Total Cost for the games: $746m with $3.2m going just on the tournaments mascot Samba (below) YOU TELL US! 
Total TV audience for the games: 650 million people BIG HIT 
Winner’s purse: $4m up from $1.5 at the last edition BIG HIT 
Most powerful rendition of a national anthem The Cranes. They waited for 39 years to sing it, and came through like canaries. HIT 
Biggest contributor: Total who paid $240m to sponsor Caf events through 2024 YOU TELL US! 
Biggest waste: $6m spent by the Ivory Coast to prepare for the tournament. MISS 
Big noise, least impact: Zaha MISS 
Most unusual request: $5,000 per game demanded by the Brave ( and greedy) Warriors per game…win or lose BIG FLOP 
Heart warming fact : Egypt the seven-time champion, get $850 per game and under $3000 if they win the cup and nobody grumbles. BIG HIT AND now PLEASE STAND A SING Nkosi sikelel' Afrika 
Cheapest ticket: $0.80 Big Hit 
Most expensive ticket: $60.00 YOU TELL US! 
Neutral Crowds most favourite player: Aristide Bance Hit 
Most asked question (as of yesterday) : Will Egypt’s 19 match unbeaten run at Afcon that stretches over 13 years finally fall? 
Please look out for our total recap of Afcon in numbers once the tournament concludes © supersport.com
